5.1 Critique of Kant’s Categorical Imperative

Bolzano’s main objection against the Categorical Imperative was
that we cannot derive from it alone — as Kant supposed —
whether a given act ought to be done or not. Kant’s instruction
to ask ourselves of a maxim whether we can will without contradicting
ourselves that it should become a universal law is of no use,
according to Bolzano, since for him there is no practical proposition
or ought proposition whose contradictory opposite is
self-contradictory. This, however, is not a decisive argument against
Kant’s Categorical Imperative for several reasons. Nevertheless,
Bolzano refused to accept the Categorical Imperative strictly and
replaced it with the utilitarian principle of “the advancement
of the general welfare”, as he proudly reports in his
autobiography (Bolzano 1836, 23).
